body: Would you all be open to a Dockerfile for using neovim and as a neovim official image? I can make the pull request. Or would you rather wait until development was more stable.

comment_data.body: Interesting; can you elaborate how such an image could be used? Would it e.g. be possible for users of this image to use their previous `.vimrc` as Neovim's `.nvimrc` without much setup? That could be handy to let people try if their favorite plugins work in Neovim, for example.

Yes, it would be perfect for trying out your config files, you could do so with the following:

``` console
$ docker run -it \ 
   -v /path/to/your/.vimrc:/home/user/.vimrc \
   -v /path/to/your/.nvimrc:/home/user/.nvimrc \
   -v /path/to/your/.vim:/home/user/.vim \
   neovim
```

Just to explain the `-v` flag is a volume, so your can move files & directories on your host into a container on run. So the command above would open neovim just as if it was on your host (but in a container) so perfectly safe for trying out and playing with! This is also exactly how I currently use vim on my computer. You can add any additional `-v` flags for loading local code files etc you want to edit in the container.

For example:

``` console
$ docker run -it \ 
   -v /path/to/your/.vimrc:/home/user/.vimrc \
   -v /path/to/your/.nvimrc:/home/user/.nvimrc \
   -v /path/to/your/jessies-code:/home/user/jessies-code \
   neovim
```

+1; as a heavy user of both vim and docker, and as someone interested in trying out neovim, this would make it super easy to play with and get a feel for how the switch would go without actually committing 100% right up front :heart:

Hey @justinmk 

To be honest I think the best way would be a repo up on dockerhub.
Then to get a Neovim-CI container going, it'd just be

```
docker run -it  --name neovim neovim/neovim-ci
```

Which is painless in comparison to the manual methods.

I think it'd be more beneficial to have a Neovim-CI (as opposed to standard Neovim) docker box as there's a ton of stuff to install before you can properly contribute to the codebase.

If such a box existed, they could start up the box and develop inside that without polluting their OS with all of the build tools.

Is there a definitive list of all of the tools anywhere? I did see the [deps](https://github.com/neovim/deps) repository and the makefiles so maybe it's easiest to infer it from there.

There are some great examples by @jessfraz in one of her [repo's](https://github.com/jessfraz/dockerfiles).

Anyway, I'm happy to start on the CI box but I'm unsure of where to begin package-wise.

> Is there a definitive list of all of the tools anywhere? 

You just need the [build prerequisites](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/wiki/Building-Neovim#build-prerequisites). If you run `make` in the Neovim directory, it will download/build all the Neovim dependencies. No need to "pollute" your system with them ;-)
@joereynolds So what is needed from us? Do we need to update the dockerhub definition as part of our CI? If you can get a script going for that we will definitely add it to our CI process.

@justinmk at the moment nothing is needed from you guys. 

Once I have built the neovim-ci image, it will need to be pushed up to dockerhub so that others can use it.
Once it's on Dockerhub and versioned in Github, perhaps we can look at making sure the neovim-ci image contains the latest packages specified from makefiles etc...

All this being said, I'd suggest you guys register your neovim name over at dockerhub while it's still free!

[https://hub.docker.com/u/neovim/](https://hub.docker.com/u/neovim/)

I took this over and am distributing neovim docker images:

The base image is alpine:

https://github.com/nvim-lsp/try.nvim/blob/master/base/Dockerfile

They are distributed via quay:
https://quay.io/repository/nvim-lsp/try.nvim

I also have control of the neovim organization on quay, and can push the base images there instead to make it more "official". There is still the case of where to do the CI for building the images (right now this is hosted in the try.nvim repo via GHA

As there is a neovim org on github, it would make sense to:
- move try.nvim in the neovim org
- use ghcr to push the images

The main advantage being that you can delegate all authentication/authorization on the published image to github organization. So as long as the neovim org is in a correct state (permissions-wise), it's pretty easy to trust that the Docker image is correct. But maybe there's another reason to use quay that I don't know

I just prefer the RedHat ecosystem and quay gives free hosting to open source projects, the docker "org" AFAIK is just a user account. I think Justin has the login.

Also try.nvim is not really "official", it just so happens to be run by one person who is semi-official :)

@mjlbach, don't you suppose to add hash (digest, `@sha256:\d+`) of the image you are basing on in case new `alpine` image will somehow fail the process of building Neovim from source and executing it? It's just a good practice to do so. To make it more reproducible.

https://github.com/nvim-lsp/try.nvim/blob/56fe2af59fc3a9f8bf97014bd3c3334f24c16da8/base/Dockerfile#L24

There is also a question about patching vulnerabilities, but since
- the image is called `try.nvim`,
- `alpine:latest` has 1–2 vuln.,
- the `quay.io/nvim-lsp/try.nvim:base-stable` has about 16 (`snyk` found only 8)
- and I don't know how to automize process of patching found vuln.,

it's up to you to patch them or not.
Thanks @Andrew15-5, I don't use neovim anymore so I went ahead and archived the repository.
